Fachstudienberatung - Universität Regensburg Fachstudienberatung - Universität Regensburg Startseite UR Startseite Fachstudienberatung Kontaktdaten Studium Anerkennungen Download Newsletter Fachstudienberatung Die Fachstudienberatung Chemie ist die Anlaufstelle bei Fragen und Problemen rund ums Chemiestudium. Egal ob Sie sich nach dem Abitur über die Chemiestudiengänge informieren möchten, bereits Chemie studieren oder von einem anderen Studiengang zur Chemie wechseln möchten, die Fachstudienberatung hilft Ihnen gerne weiter. Chemie können Sie in unterschiedlichen Studiengängen studieren. Zum einen gibt es den konsekutiven Bachelor-Master-Studiengang Chemie, zum anderen gibt es die Lehramtsstudiengänge, in denen Sie Chemie mit einem weiteren Fach kombiniert studieren können. Auf der Internetseite der Fakultät für Chemie und Pharmazie können Sie sich bereits vorab über die einzelnen Studiengänge informieren. Bitte folgen Sie den entsprechenden Links: Bachelorstudiengang Chemie Masterstudiengänge Chemie Lehramtsstudiengänge Chemie Ihre Fragen richten Sie bitte an den zuständigen Ansprechpartner Ihrer Fachstudienberatung (siehe Kontaktdaten). Dr. Monica A. Totir - 01.10.2013 11:42 STARTSEITE UR Studienberatung Kontakt zur Studienberatung für B.Sc. und M.Sc. Chemie: Email für Lehramt Chemie: Email

Studiengangskoordination Chemie - Universität Regensburg Studiengangskoordination Chemie - Universität Regensburg Startseite UR Startseite Fachstudienberatung Studium Anerkennungen Download Newsletter Studiengangskoordination Chemie Herzlich Willkommen bei der Studiengangskoordination Chemie Die Studiengangskoordination Chemie möchte Sie gerne auf dem Weg durch Ihr Chemiestudium begleiten und Sie mit Rat und Tat unterstützen, wenn Sie Fragen oder Probleme haben sollten. Neben der Fachstudienberatung für Bachelor und Master Chemie kümmert sich die Studiengangskoordination Chemie auch um die Anerkennung von extern erworbenen Studienleistungen, Lehrveranstaltungsevaluationen, Qualitätssicherung und Studierbarkeit unserer Studiengänge u.v.m. Anerkennung extern erworbener Studienleistungen - Universität Regensburg

Anerkennung extern erworbener Studienleistungen - Universität Regensburg Anerkennung extern erworbener Studienleistungen - Universität Regensburg Startseite UR Startseite Fachstudienberatung Studium Anerkennungen Download Newsletter Anerkennung extern erworbener Studienleistungen Sie können sich extern erworbene Studienleistungen (nach Auslandsstudium, bei Studiengangwechsel etc.) für das Chemiestudium an der UR anerkennen lassen. Dabei muss geprüft werden, ob ihre erbrachten Leistungen zu den an der UR angebotenen Lehrveranstaltungen äquivalent sind. Folgende Unterlagen werden zur Anerkennung benötigt: Transcript of Records bzw. Übersicht ihrer Studienleistungen (inkl. Note, Leistungspunkte, SWS) Inhaltsangaben der einzelnen Lehrveranstaltungen Forschungsberichte, Protokolle Anerkennungen im Bachelor- und Masterstudiengang Chemie Bitte vereinbaren Sie einen Termin mit der Studiengangskoordination Chemie. Hier werden die Anerkennungsunterlagen vorbereitet und den zuständigen Professoren zur Prüfung weitergeleitet. Folgende Professoren sind derzeit für die Anerkennung von Studienleistungen zuständig: Prof. Dr. A. Pfitzner (Anorganische Chemie) Prof. Dr. B. König (Organische Chemie) Prof. Dr. W. Kunz (Physikalische Chemie) Prof. Dr. J. Wegener (Analytische Chemie) Prof. Dr. B. Dick (Mathematik, Physik) Anerkennungen im Lehramtsstudium Chemie Bitte vereinbaren Sie einen Termin mit der Studienberatung für Lehramt Chemie. Das zur Anerkennung benötigte Formblatt finden Sie hier. Die Anerkennungsunterlagen werden vom jeweiligen Modulverantwortlichen geprüft. Dr. Monica A. Totir - 01.10.2013 11:38 STARTSEITE UR Studienberatung Kontakt zur Studienberatung für B.Sc. und M.Sc. Chemie: Email für Lehramt Chemie: Email

Research - Universität Regensburg Research - Universität Regensburg UR Home Home Curriculum Vitae Group Members Alumni Teaching Publications Research Diary (in German) Research Our research interests revolve around the discovery of new, reactive transition metal compounds and the development of new applications for these compounds in synthesis and catalysis. Anions Anionic Transition Metal Compounds with Metals in Low Oxidation States: In this exploratory project, we investigate organometallic complexes that can be used as sources of "Mx-"- and "CpMx-" synthons (M = transition metal, Cp = cyclopentadienyl ligand) for the synthesis of unusual new compounds and in catalysis. Transition metal anions of this type have scarcely been applied due to the limited availability of suitable synthesis equivalents. Starting with anionic synthons, we synthesize new metal clusters, "functionalized" transition metal anions with an interesting subsequent chemistry, and novel multimetallic complexes. The catalytic properties of the anions investigated in this project are being studied as well. Our investigations focus on iron, which is of particular interest for catalytic processes as an abundant, non-toxic, and environmentally friendly metal. Hydrides Cooperative Reactivity of Metal Atoms in Polynuclear Transition Metal Hydrides: This project explores the cooperative reactivity of novel mono- and multinuclear polyhydrido complexes. The ability of oligonuclear hydrides to activate C-H and C-C bonds through a multimetallic mechanism and their catalytic activity lie at the heart of our investigations. Another focus lies on metal-ligand cooperativity in NHC ruthenium complexes (NHC = N-heterocyclic carbene) in catalytic reactions. Photocatalysis Selective Oxyfunctionalization via Coupled Redox Photocatalysis: The selective oxidation of alkenes and aliphatic hydrocarbons represents a major challenge in modern chemistry. In nature, these oxidations are performed successfully under mild conditions by metalloenzymes such as cytochrome P450 and non-heme based oxygenases. In the lab, a plethora of successful transition metal-based catalysts have been developed. However, only few catalysts are able to use atmospheric oxygen as the terminal oxidant, and these rare examples still show poor selectivities. Moreover, few examples for photocatalytic oxyfunctionalizations have been described to date. In this project, we develop new photocatalytic methods for the selective oxyfunctionalization of hydrocarbons. Preferably, atmospheric oxygen is used as the oxidant. The investigations are conducted in the framework of the research training group "Chemical Photocatalysis" (GRK 1626). Dirk Herrmann - 05.03.2014 14:36 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Inorganic Chemistry Robert Wolf Group Prof. Dr. Robert Wolf Universitätsstr. 31 93053 Regensburg Email Tel. +49 941 943-4485 Fax +49 941 943-814485 Büro: CH 22.2.83

Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology - Universität Regensburg

Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology - Universität Regensburg Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology - Universität Regensburg UR Home Homepage Research Members Publications Career Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology Welcome to the website of the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology at the University of Regensburg! Research Research at the department of pharmacology and toxicology is focused to characterize mechanisms and physiological/pathophysiological role of NO/ANP and cyclic nucleotides (e.g. cGMP) which could be the basis for the development of innovative pharmacological concepts. At the department of pharmacology and toxicology the following research topics are preferentially analysed: Signalling mechanisms and physiology/pathophysiology of NO/ANP/cGMP in the heart and circulation system, in platelets and in the kidney Signal transduction and substrate proteins of the cGMP-dependent protein kinase inter alia the substrate protein IRAG Intracellular calcium regulation Function of cyclic pyrimidine nucleotides Pharmacokinetic analysis e.g. of antibiotics Teaching The diverse lectures and courses for pharmacy anc chemistry students are described in the section ?Studium? on our german homepage. Jens Schlossmann - 27.05.2014 10:38 HOMEPAGE UR Pharmacology and Toxicology Prof. Dr. Jens Schlossmann Phone: +49-941-943-4771 Fax: +49-941-943-4772 email

Research Group Prof. Werner KUNZ - Universität Regensburg

Research Group Prof. Werner KUNZ - Universität Regensburg Research Group Prof. Werner KUNZ - Universität Regensburg UR Home Homepage Professor Werner KUNZ News News for Students Courses Research Staff Alumni Publications Open Positions How to find us Research Group Prof. Werner KUNZ Welcome to the Chair of Physical Chemistry II ? link to the Solution Chemistry Group home page Characterization, conception and practical application of complex and nano-structured liquids and their interfaces define the central research interests of the Regensburg Solution Chemistry Group. We focus on environmentally friendly chemicals and the formulation of new consumer products in the field of cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and household products from basic research to end-products. Our lecture and exercise courses and lab classes are in the field of thermodynamics, colloidal, solution and interface chemistry, product formulation, electrochemistry and reaction kinetics, nanoscience and computer simulations of liquids and their interfaces. Current research topics at the Department of Physical Chemistry II - Universität Regensburg

Current research topics at the Department of Physical Chemistry II - Universität Regensburg Current research topics at the Department of Physical Chemistry II - Universität Regensburg UR Home Homepage Professor Werner KUNZ News News for Students Courses Research Current topics Laboratories and equipment Staff Alumni Publications Open Positions How to find us Current research topics at the Department of Physical Chemistry II Solvents and hydrotropes To solubilise a component in a solvent, the solvent must be well characterised. Recently, we participated in the proposition of a new type of solvent classification based on the COSOM-RS theory [168]. Together with our colleagues in Lille we also considered new types of solvents that in part show also surfactant properties. Such a hybrid class of liquids we called solvo-surfactants. In particular we were interested in glycerol derivatives [109] and so-called dowanols© [69,72,116,136,68] and related structures [134]. In this context it seemed of interest to illustrate the continuous cross-over of pure solvents to real surfactants and of mixtures between both [86,88,92]. Temperature-composition diagram for PnP/water system at 20 kPa [136]. Surfactants, Micelles and Classical Microemulsions So many research groups and industrial companies work on surfactants. Are there still any open questions? We thought that three aspects would be worth being studied: - How do decrease the Krafft temperature of surfactants? Our idea was to use choline as a natural, biological cation that significantly reduces the solubilisation temperature of surfactants [130,144]. This is true for carboxylates and alkylsulfates, the latter being much less sensitive to water hardness [C5]. - How to make olive oil and related fats miscible with water? To this purpose we studied so-called extended surfactants and indeed could make clear stable mini-emulsions with a minimum amount of surfactant [159,165,170,183]. - How to achieve the spontaneous formation of vesicles as simply as possible and with biocompatible surfactants? This question was considered in several papers [110,113,135]. In this context we also studied mixtures of cationic and anionic surfactants [128,145,148,154]. Micelles and microemulsions are also classical systems that have been studied thousands of times. We asked following questions: - How to characterise microemulsions by classical scattering techniques [43,62,58,97] and less common techniques such as dielectric relaxation spectroscopy [46,47,57,79,85,98] under the guidance of our specialist Prof. Richard Buchner, and some other techniques [56,59]? - What is the interplay between these structures and enzymatic reactions? How can such reactions be optimised by an appropriate design of nano-structured solutions? [39,40,41,48,50,84,87,91,132]. - Can enzymatic reactions also be performed in microemulsions in supercritical CO2? [51, 95]. - How to make green microemulsions? [185]. - What is the influence of surfactants on polymer adsorption and washing-off processes? [66,71]. Penetration scan of ChC12 at 20°C acquired at 100x magnification between half-crossed polarizers, showing the following sequence of mesophases: L1, I1', I2'', H1, V1 and a gel+solid region. [174] (Non-)aqueous electrolyte solutions As a continuation of Josef Barthel?s work (Josef Barthel is the founder of the chair of physical chemistry II at Regensburg university), we pursued the study of the structure and thermodynamics of non-aqueous electrolyte solutions [11,12,13,19,65,70,73,81,82,83,89,99,136,146], essentially with Jean-Pierre Simonin in Paris and some aqueous ones [117,126,127] with our Ukrainian colleague Elena Tsurko. Experimental osmotic coefficients of (LiBr + DMAc) at different temperatures. The theoretical curves are generated using the extended Pitzer model of Archer. [82] Theory of electrolytes A long time ago I learnt to model aqueous and non-aqueous electrolyte solutions [10,12,16,17,22,29,30,32] both in Regensburg and under the guidance of Pierre Turq in Paris. Whereas first a relatively complex solvent-averaged modelling was intended, we turned later on to efficient working equations for engineers [49,53,67,100,104,123]. We acknowledge the tremendous work done by Jean-Pierre Simonin at the University Pierre et Marie in Paris. Distribution of NaNO3 ions at the air-aqueous solution interface with and without dispersion forces at 1M conzentration. [61] Specific ion effects Inspired by Barry Ninham during his six month stay in Regensburg in 2004, we began to get interested in specific ion effects. At first we followed the idea of dispersion forces to describe these effects [61,74,75,77,80]. However, we soon realized that the problem is much more complex. Therefore, we went back to experiments and considered specific ion effects in a multitude of systems, e.g. in ?simple? electrolyte solutions [90,94,103,108], surfactants systems (association colloids) [125,141,143,187], enzymatic systems [76,96] and on biological membranes [114]. The collaboration with Pavel Jungwirth and his group as well as with Roland Netz and his group (especially Dominik Horinek, and Joachim Dzubiella) and finally discussions with Kim D. Collins have been of great importance for us to understand these effects [101,105,106,118,124,127,129, 131,141,153,155,157]. We could even use them to specifically design new surfactants [130,144]. Ordering of anionic surfactant headgroups and the corresponding counterions regarding their capabilities to form close pairs. The green arrows mean strong interactions (close ion pairs). [141] Ionic Liquids Having worked for a long time with electrolytes, solvents and surfactants, it was natural to get interested in Ionic Liquids, i.e. salts that are liquid below 100°C or even at room temperature. In contrast to many other groups we concentrated on two queuestions: How can we conceive Ionic Liquids that are not based on the classical imidazolium or other organic cations? In this context we had two major achievements: the discovery that short-chain alkyl-oligoether carboxylates are liquid at low temperatures even with sodium as counterion and second that choline as counterion can also lead to Ionic liquids when combined with convenient middle- to long chain carboxylates [C3,142,164,169,172,174]. Can we incorporate Ionic Liquids in micellar and microemulsion systems [112] to make aqueous systems over wide temperature ranges? This question we answered in details in the following papers: [139,156,160,161,162,163,167,173,176,184]. Sketch of the postulated crosslinked structure of liquid [Na][TOTO] with strongly bound Na+???carbocxylate ion pairs and weaker Na+???ether-oxygen interactions. [164] Mixtures of carbonates and silicates ? from nanocrystals to biomorphs and silica gardens Having heard fascinating lectures by Stephen Hyde, Canberra, and Juan-Manuel García-Ruiz, Granada, I got interested in the world of complex structures made of simple ions in aqueous solutions such as silicates and carbonates. I wanted to understand the origin of the phenomenon of biomorphs and the origin of curvature that simple ions create by an amazing self-aggregation process during crystallisation. Several papers came out of this research[115,119,121,133,137,140, 149,166,179,186,188]. A side-effect of this subject was the characterisation of silica-gardens, an old subject that even found entrance in school presentations [181]. In a somewhat related research topic collaboration with the German Papiertechnische Stiftung (Foundation of Paper Industry) led to the fabrication of interesting hollow oxide microspheres [122,150]. Chemical garden....are beautiful structures that show fascinating membrane and diaphragm properties. [181] Structured aqueous alginate gels Following a fascinating idea of our colleague Prof. Klaus Heckmann in Regensburg, Rainer Müller and I were interested in alginate gels that, under certain conditions, make highly ordered gels when in contact with bivalent cations. Driven by a dissipative process the gels undergo a self-organising process thus forming pores of up to 2 cm length that are parallel und uniform. These pores can be used as guidelines for nerve axon growth. The whole material can also be used as templates for well-defined structures [102,111,171]. Ultrastucture of alginate-based anisotropic capillary gels (ACH), (a) cross - and (b) longitudinal section. [102] Formulation chemistry and the development of a natural water-soluble insect repellent Formulation is one of our central activities. We develop products based on solutions and surfactants for many international companies well-known in the field of cosmetics, household products and pharmaceuticals. In the SKH GmbH we also conceive products against bad odours in industrial plants, for better solvent management etc. A particularly interesting product came out of a collaboration with the local company BioGents that is specialised in insect attractants. Further to formulations of their products we managed to create a natural insect repellent. What is more, we could transform it in a simple and environmentally friendly way to a highly active water-soluble repellent [151,152,175,C6]. Cemical structures of cis- and trans-para-menthane-3,8-diol isomers. (+)-cis and (-)-trans-p-menthane-3,8-diols are mainly present in the solution according to Takasago (Paris, France).Traces of (-) -cis and (+)-trans isomers can also be detected by gas chromatography (Drapeau). [151] Reactions under hydrothermal conditions Water and many aqueous solutions are naturally green solvents. Under hydrothermal conditions (between 150 and 250°C and under its own pressure) water has properties that significantly differ from its usual behaviour at room temperature. With increasing temperatures the dielectric constant and hence the polarity of water decreases rapidly and in parallel the self-dissociation of water increases. As a result, water under hydrothermal conditions can be interesting as solvent for many organic reactions [178,182]. This is a study that is complementary to our former investigations of enzymatic reactions performed in microemulsions in supercritical CO2 [51, 95], see before. An artist's view on hydrothermal reactions showing Denis Papin, one of the inventors of the autoclave (by Ekaterina Shilova). Research at the Department of Physical Chemistry II - Universität Regensburg

Research at the Department of Physical Chemistry II - Universität Regensburg Research at the Department of Physical Chemistry II - Universität Regensburg UR Home Homepage Professor Werner KUNZ News News for Students Courses Research Current topics Laboratories and equipment Staff Alumni Publications Open Positions How to find us Research at the Department of Physical Chemistry II Characterization, conception and practical application of complex and nano-structured liquids and their interfaces define the central research interests of the Regensburg Solution Chemistry Group. The major focus is on homogeneous, transparent and thermodynamically stable liquids, such as solutions of electrolytes, surfactants, polymers, bio-molecules as well as Ionic Liquids and micro-emulsions. Other systems such as emulsions, or structured solutions in supercritical carbon dioxide are also investigated. The self-organisation of molecular liquid systems and specific ion effects (e.g. the Hofmeister series) in nature and technology are in the center of interest. To characterize structure, dynamics, reaction kinetics, and thermodynamic properties of such systems a multitude of experimental and theoretical methods is employed. From the view-point of basic research the interplay between solvation and association, between hydrophobic and electrostatic interactions, is explored to understand the self-organisation of molecular systems and its consequences on the macroscopic properties of the sample. The gained knowledge is often rapidly transferred to applied research. For instance new green solvents and surfactants and environmentally friendly Ionic Liquids are designed, as well as green insect repellents, anti-odorising products etc. Generally, the necessary high-precision equipment is designed and developed by the group in collaboration with the faculty workshops. More sophisticated experiments such as neutron scattering or special microscopy techniques are performed at various international research centres and institutes Please follow the link to take a view from our equipment and Laboratories In order to efficiently transform the obtained knowledge to the design of industrial products or new technical processes, the SKH Company for applied and technical chemistry was founded in 2000. The firm is recognized as an associate institute of the University of Regensburg. This company also offers services in the field of product formulation, especially of cosmetics, household products and pharmaceutics. In the future, the focus of our research will be mainly on two areas: Conception of environmentally friendly solvents, surfactants, and liquid solutions for chemical and industrial processes. Environmentally friendly extraction of plants (essential oils, biopolymers etc.) for the design of highly added value chemicals based on renewable feed stocks (not for fuel production). The vision is a new view on European agriculture that becomes more and more independent of subsidising. Our current research can be subdivided into ten topics all related to solution chemistry. Please follow the links below to lern more about specific subjects: Solvents and Hydrotropes Surfactants, Micelles and Microemulsions (Non-)aqueous Electrolyte Solutions Theory of Electrolytes Specific Ion Effects Ionic Liquids Mixtures of Carbonates and Silicates ? from Nanocrystals to Biomorphs and Silica Gardens Structured Aqueous Alginate Gels Formulation chemistry and the development of a natural water-soluble insect repellent Reactions under Hydrothermal Conditions Note that we are working on several more topics of minor extensiveness, mostly in collaboration with colleagues all over the world. The behaviour of polymers in aqueous solutions and adsorbed to solid surfaces, as studied by AFM might be of interest for a broad readership [66,71] as well as the unified concept of curvature, packing parameter and hydrophilic-hydrophobic difference in surfactant solutions [138]. Peter Karageorgiev - 04.07.2012 13:42 INSTITUTE OF PHYSICAL AND THEORETICAL CHEMISTRY Solution Chemistry Group PCII / Solution Chemistry: Research Our perspective green topics: Green Solvents Green Ionic Liquids Green Reactions Green Surfact./Hydrotrp.

The gained knowledge is often rapidly transferred to applied research. For instance new green solvents and surfactants and environmentally friendly Ionic Liquids are designed, as well as green insect repellents, anti-odorising products etc. Generally, the necessary high-precision equipment is designed and developed by the group in collaboration with the faculty workshops. More sophisticated experiments such as neutron scattering or special microscopy techniques are performed at various international research centres and institutes Please follow the link to take a view from our equipment and Laboratories In order to efficiently transform the obtained knowledge to the design of industrial products or new technical processes, the SKH Company for applied and technical chemistry was founded in 2000. The firm is recognized as an associate institute of the University of Regensburg. This company also offers services in the field of product formulation, especially of cosmetics, household products and pharmaceutics. In the future, the focus of our research will be mainly on two areas: Conception of environmentally friendly solvents, surfactants, and liquid solutions for chemical and industrial processes. Environmentally friendly extraction of plants (essential oils, biopolymers etc.) for the design of highly added value chemicals based on renewable feed stocks (not for fuel production). The vision is a new view on European agriculture that becomes more and more independent of subsidising. Our current research can be subdivided into ten topics all related to solution chemistry. Please follow the links below to lern more about specific subjects: Solvents and Hydrotropes Surfactants, Micelles and Microemulsions (Non-)aqueous Electrolyte Solutions Theory of Electrolytes Specific Ion Effects Ionic Liquids Mixtures of Carbonates and Silicates ? from Nanocrystals to Biomorphs and Silica Gardens Structured Aqueous Alginate Gels Formulation chemistry and the development of a natural water-soluble insect repellent Reactions under Hydrothermal Conditions Note that we are working on several more topics of minor extensiveness, mostly in collaboration with colleagues all over the world. The behaviour of polymers in aqueous solutions and adsorbed to solid surfaces, as studied by AFM might be of interest for a broad readership [66,71] as well as the unified concept of curvature, packing parameter and hydrophilic-hydrophobic difference in surfactant solutions [138]. Peter Karageorgiev - 04.07.2012 13:42 INSTITUTE OF PHYSICAL AND THEORETICAL CHEMISTRY Solution Chemistry Group PCII / Solution Chemistry: Research Our perspective green topics: Green Solvents Green Ionic Liquids Green Reactions Green Surfact./Hydrotrp.
Apl. Professor Richard Buchner - Universität Regensburg

Apl. Professor Richard Buchner - Universität Regensburg Apl. Professor Richard Buchner - Universität Regensburg UR Home Homepage Professor Werner KUNZ News News for Students Courses Research Staff Professor W. Kunz Apl. Prof. R. Buchner PD Dr. R. Müller Permanent staff Graduate Students Retired Professors Alumni Publications Open Positions How to find us Apl. Professor Richard Buchner Vita Curriculum Vitae 1986 PhD with Prof. J. Barthel, Universität Regensburg (The Influence of Electrolytes and Non-polar Substances on the Dielectric Properties of Methanol and Water in the Gigahertz Range). 1986 Akademischer Rat (senior research assistant) at the Institut für Physikalische und Theoretische Chemie, Universität Regensburg, specializing on dielectric relaxation spectroscopy. 1986/87 NATO Research Fellow with Prof. J. Yarwood, University of Durham, UK: Far-infrared spectroscopy of liquids with intermolecular hydrogen bonds. 1996 Guest Scientist at the Dept. of Molecular Design and Engineering (Prof. H. Nomura), Nagoya University, Japan (Fellow of the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science). 1997 Akademischer Oberrat 1997 Habilitation in Physical Chemistry with Habilitationsschrift (thesis) Development of a Time-Domain Refiectometer for the Investigation of Ion-pair Relaxation in Electrolyte Solutions. 1997 Privatdozent at the Universität Regensburg. 1997/98 Visiting Research Fellow of Murdoch University, Australia 2003 Außerplanmäßiger Professor (adjunct professor) 2007 Akademischer Direktor Personal member of the Gesellschaft Deutscher Chemiker, the Deutsche Bunsen-Gesellschaft für Physikalische Chemie, the European Molecular Liquids Group (Chairman 2007-2013), and the Deutsche Gesellschaft der JSPS-Stipendiaten. Editorial Board Member of the Journal of Molecular Liquids, the Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data, and the Zeitschrift für Physikalische Chemie. B 116 (2012) 314-323.Available online at http://epub.uni-regensburg.de/24355 Research Research Interests of apl. Prof. Dr. Richard Buchner The complete Information also in Our Research: Speciation, Structure and Dynamics in Complex Liquids The group mainly uses dielectric relaxation spectroscopy, accompanied by conductivity and viscosity measurements, to probe transport properties, structure and cooperative dynamics of complex liquids. Our facilities are supplemented by external cooperation partners specializing in Terahertz spectroscopy (M. Walther, Freiburg, DE) Optical Kerr-effect spectroscopy (OKE; K. Wynne & D. Turton, Glasgow, UK) Time-resolved IR spectroscopy (H. Bakker, Amsterdam, NL) Thermodynamic measurements (G. Hefter, Murdoch, AU) Computer simulations (C. Schröder & O. Steinhauser, Vienna, AT) Small-angle X-ray scattering (T. Sato, Ueda, JP) Current topics are Electrolyte solutions are relevant in many areas, ranging from biology and geochemistry to technical applications. We study for aqueous and nonaqueous solutions Solute & solvent dynamics relaxation mechanism, activation parameters Solute-solvent interactions solvation numbers Solute-solute interactions species present, ion-pair concentrations, association constants We found Multi-step ion-pair formation common for strongly associating electrolytes Ion-cloud relaxation not negligible for weakly associating electrolytes Strongly and weakly bound hydration water can be distinguished Bulk solvent dynamics may be affected by solute Recent publications: A. Eiberweiser and R. Buchner, Ion-pair or Ion-cloud Relaxation? On the Origin of Small-amplitude Low-frequency Relaxations of Weakly Associating Aqueous Electrolytes, J. Mol. Liq. DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2012.03.025 H. M. A. Rahman, G. Hefter and R. Buchner, Hydration of Formate and Acetate Ions by Dielectric Relaxation Spectroscopy, J. Phys. Chem. B 116 (2012) 314-323. DOI: 10.1021/jp207504d A. P?aczek, G. Hefter, H. M. A. Rahman and R. Buchner, Dielectric Relaxation Study of the Ion Solvation and Association of NaCF3SO3, Mg(CF3SO3)2 and Ba(ClO4)2 in N,N-Dimethylformamide, J. Phys. Chem. B 115 (2011) 2234-2242. DOI: 10.1021/jp1116307 Ionic Liquids Ionic liquids are room-temperature molten salts with many potential applications, either in the pure state or mixed with conventional solvents. Pure ionic liquids exhibit Complicated dynamics extending from a few hundred femtoseconds to several nanoseconds (frequency range ~10 MHz to 10 THz) Significant THz-contributions from intermolecular vibrations and librations Ion reorientation through large-angle jumps Ion caging on nanosecond time-scale Aggregate formation for imidazolium ILs IL+solvent mixtures show Smooth transition from electrolyte-solution like to molten-salt like behaviour at IL mole fractions xIL » 0.3-0.5 Compared to pure IL, dynamics in molten-salt like region accelerated (solvent ?lubricates? IL) Solvent-dependent degree of ion pairing at low xIL Generally weak ion solvation Recent publications: J. Hunger, T. Sonnleitner, L. Liu, R. Buchner, M. Bonn, and H. J. Bakker, Hydrogen-Bond Jump Reorientation Dynamics in a Protic Ionic Liquid, J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 3 (2012) 3034-3038. DOI: 10.1021/jz301247nH. A. Stoppa, J. Hunger, G. Hefter and R. Dr. Rainer Müller VITA Short biography Rainer Müller was born on December 22, 1968 in Schrobenhausen, Bavaria (Germany). He studied chemistry at the University of Regensburg where he graduated in February 1995. His diploma-thesis was entitled "Synthesis and physicochemical characterization of biologically degradable cationic polyelectrolytes" and was prepared at the Institute of Physical and Macromolecular Chemistry under supervision of Professor Klaus Heckmann. He obtained his PhD in February 1998 at the Laboratory of Interface Chemistry which was the follow-up institution after Professor Heckmann´s retirement. The PhD-thesis was entitled "Synthesis of corrosion-inhibiting coupling agents for microelectronic devices". After attaining his doctoral degree, Rainer Müller was scientific co-worker at the Laboratory of Interface Chemistry where he established a research group focused on colloid and interface chemistry with special emphasis on biomaterials and tissue engineering. In December 2000 he became scientific assistant at the Institute of Physical and Theoretical Chemistry of the University of Regensburg headed by Professor Werner Kunz starting his habilitation work. He initiated several co-operations with the Departments of Trauma Surgery, Operative Dentistry, and Neurology of the University Hospital of Regensburg and other univeristy institutes which were funded by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) or by the Bavarian State Ministry of Sciences, Research and the Arts. In November 2009 he finished his habilitation-thesis entitled "Chemical modification of biomaterial surfaces and scaffolds to direct biological responses in regenerative medicine". In Juli 2010 he was appointed 'Privatdozent' at the University of Regensburg. Since August 2011 Rainer Müller is senior research assistant (Akademischer Rat) at the Institute of Physical and Theoretical Chemistry of the University of Regensburg. He gives lecture courses and laboratory classes for undergraduate students of chemistry, biochemistry and biology. Software - Universität Regensburg Software - Universität Regensburg UR Home Home Computer Centre Your CC Account Support Software Hardware Teaching and Learning IT Services Software Software on Offer Our computer centre gives needful advice to help you choose, buy, install, update, and de-install software. We provide various Linux and Windows operating systems, installation and update services as well as accessories and application software. Providing Software We provide various software packages that are specially adapted and easy to use for your daily work and are compatible with our various IT services such as network drives, printing services, network services, virus protection, GroupWare, etc. You will also find a large offer of free or licensable application software (via the software buying department) - from Office products to multimedia- and image processing and software for academic applications in the Softwarekatalog. Software Buying Department If staff members of the university and the university hospital need programmes that require a license, our software buying department helps in choosing and obtaining them. Various programmes are available for students in the framework of special distribution programmes. Read more in our MSDNAA, Corel Campus Agreement, SPSS or CITAVI instructions (in German). Internet in Your Dormitory - Universität Regensburg

Internet in Your Dormitory - Universität Regensburg Internet in Your Dormitory - Universität Regensburg UR Home Home Computer Centre Your CC Account Support WiFi Password Internet in Your Dormitory Printing VPN Software Hardware Teaching and Learning IT Services Internet in Your Dormitory Internet in Your Hall of Residence Basic Requirement: A valid CC account Every user has a user name and a corresponding password which are both necessary to log in at the cip-pools and the hall of residence. It looks like this: .vip12345.5.stud.uni-regensburg.de 1. Buy coupons birne You can buy coupons at the supermarket or at the cafeterias and nearly all shops on campus (with the exception of Bücher Pustet) and at the university hospital kiosk. They are called ?Wertcoupons? in German, which translates as ?coupons of value?. Please note that you need about EUR 10 for your cable and the hall fee. 2. Use the cable to connect your computer to the socket. Network cables are available at the helpdesk and can only be paid with money you have on your electronic account. 3. Open browser and enter: https://www-wohnheim.uni-regensburg.de This site is always accessible, even if you are not registered. You can manage your account from here. 4. Buy and book coupons In order to use your computer in a hall of residence, you have to pay a monthly fee of EUR 1 (EUR 6 /semester). The equivalent amount has to be on your electronic account BEFORE you register your computer or extend your registration. The dates for the full amounts are 1 April and 1 November respectively. You can book an unused coupon to your account here: https://www-wohnheim.uni-regensburg.de If you want to book from a CIP pool, use this address: https://www-cgi.uni-regensburg.de/Einrichtungen/RZ/Benutzer/Allgemein/coupon.phtml 5. Register your computer a) Open https://www-wohnheim.uni-regensburg.de and log in to your personal status page (see image 1 on the next page) b) In order to register your computer, please fill in the following forms. By clicking on the Auto button you can make your computer find its physical address automatically. c) Read the operational regulations concerning the use of private computers in a hall of residence and guarantee that you will adhere to them by checking the box right under your registration data. d) Click ?New registration? As a resident of a dormitory you can use the network of the university with your own computer (desktop or laptop) with all public services including access to the internet. Change registration This is your button of choice if you have a new computer or moved to another room in the dorm. Delete registration Every registration that is not actively extended at the end of the semester is deleted. For any computer you sign off before the end of the semester you get back the money you did not use, i.e. if you delete the registration one month after the beginning of the semester you get five euros back of the six you initially paid. Extend your registration At the end of every semester you are asked to extend your registration. The computer centre charges you another EUR 6 for the next semester as your contribution to use the network of the university. This can only be done in the following time frames: for the summer semester: 1 April ? 30 April for the winter semester: 1 October ? 31 October Note: If you fail to extend your registration, it will be deleted by 1 May or 1 November respectively and a new registration becomes necessary. Use AUTO-button only with your OWN computer/notebook. Infostand - 24.07.2012 11:17 HOMEPAGE UR Computer Centre Support for students Helpdesk Phone 0941 943-4444 Computer Centre Secretary's Office phone 0941 943-4898 fax 0941 943-4857 Contact

Printing - Universität Regensburg Printing - Universität Regensburg UR Home Home Computer Centre Your CC Account Support WiFi Password Internet in Your Dormitory Printing VPN Software Hardware Teaching and Learning IT Services Printing General Information You need to pay if you want to use the printers at the university. Your CC account includes an electronic account that you can charge online to pay for printing. Please charge your electronic account with coupons (Wertcoupons) before use. You can buy coupons (with a value of EUR 2, 5, 10 or 20) in all cafeterias and nearly all shops on campus (with the exception of Bücher Pustet) and at the university hospital kiosk. Staff members must fill out the Procurement Application Form so money can be transferred from the chair?s account to the CC account. In order to install network printers, office printers and printers of the CC print room you can use a Windows installation programme, which is easy to use. CIP Pools CIP Pools All CIP pools of Universität Regensburg are equipped with laser printers for all users. The local pool printers are preset for black-and-white prints. For more special printing jobs like link colour printing or jobs larger than 20 pages and bigger formats you can use our CC printing centre in the machine shop. printing centre Printing Centre You may use not only the black-and-white printers in the CIP pools, but also the RIO printers of the computer centre. The printing jobs for RIO printers can also be initiated from the CIP pool computers. Please come to the machine shop of the computer centre to collect your printed copies. You will find the entrance to the machine shop underneath the steps at the main entrance of the computer centre. The RIO printers are excellent for colour printing, larger printing jobs (more than 20 pages) and large formats. Please find a detailed description of our printing services. Opening Times of the Printing Centre Monday-Thursday 8.00-18.00 Friday 8.00-15.30 Prices Prices The printers vary as considerable as to quality and printing costs. The choice of the printer depends on the printing job: for standard texts with B&W images: CIP-pool printer for prints larger than A3: plotter for printing jobs of more that 50 pages: RIO_DRUCKER or RIO_LASER for colour printing in A4 or A3: RIO_FARBE Please allow up to 30 minutes if you use the printer in the machine shop depending on the printing job. The RIO Printer Database Enquiry helps you to find the right printer for your printing job. Pooldrucker (HP-Laserjet 4) for lecture notes and seminar papers A4 B&W recycled paper 4 cents per page RIO_DRUCKER (HP Laserjet 9000) for lecture notes and seminar papers A4: 4 cents per page A3: 8 cents per page B&W recycled paper print on both sides of a page (duplex) brochure printing up to 10 pages stapling up to 50 pages RIO_LASER (HP Laserjet 8150) for seminar papers A4: 4 cents per page A3: 8 cents per page B&W white paper print on both sides of a page (duplex) RIO_FARBE (HP ColorLaserjet 9500) for colour printing A4: 25 cents per page A3: 50 cents per page colour printing smooth white paper print on both sides of a page (duplex) brochure printing up to 10 pages stapling up to 50 pages RIO_PLOTTER 3 (HP Designjet 5500) for posters A4: EUR 0.50 A3: EUR 0.99 A2: EUR 1.99 A1: EUR 3.99 A0: EUR 7.99 RIO_Folie (Tectronix Phaser 850DP) for transparencies A4: EUR 1 colour printing transparency/white paper Infostand - 23.01.2013 09:10 HOMEPAGE UR Computer Centre Support for students Helpdesk Phone 0941 943-4444 Computer Centre Secretary's Office phone 0941 943-4898 fax 0941 943-4857 Contact

VPN for Mac OS - Universität Regensburg

VPN for Mac OS - Universität Regensburg VPN for Mac OS - Universität Regensburg UR Home Home Computer Centre Your CC Account Support WiFi Password Internet in Your Dormitory Printing VPN Mac OS Windows Software Hardware Teaching and Learning IT Services VPN for Mac OS Installing the Juniper VPN-Client Open your browser and go to http://vpn.uni-regensburg.de , and enter your credentials. You will be redirected to https://sslgate.uni-regensburg.de. Accept the certificate and allow access for the installation. Using the Juniper VPN-Client Connect 1. Make sure you have a working connection to the internet. 2. Start the Juniper VPN-Client. You can find it at programs ? Network Connect 3. Enter your credentials into the window that pops up. 4. Choose your desired profile out of the following three: Vpn_default: All your connections will be encrypted and redirected via the university. Vpn_profile1: All your connections will be encrypted and redirected via the university, but your computer will be accessible from a local network. This will be necessary if e.g. you want to use your network-printer at home. Vpn_profile2: Only university-sites will be encrypted and redirected. All other websites will go via your internet provider. 5. Click ?Login? to connect. 6. Once you are connected correctly, you should see a yellow closed lock. Cutting the Connection Click ?Abmelden? (Log off) in the window of the VPN-client. Further Information Please check if you are at https://sslgate.uni-regensburg.de when you enter your credentials. If you have connection drop-outs please check if you are still connected to the vpn-network: right-click on the lock -> ?Normalansicht? -> under ?Status? you should see ?verbunden? (connected). Infostand - 24.07.2012 11:20 HOMEPAGE UR Computer Centre Support for students Helpdesk Phone 0941 943-4444 Computer Centre Secretary's Office phone 0941 943-4898 fax 0941 943-4857 Contact

WiFi - Universität Regensburg WiFi - Universität Regensburg UR Home Home Computer Centre Your CC Account Support WiFi Password Internet in Your Dormitory Printing VPN Software Hardware Teaching and Learning IT Services WiFi Welcome to the Wireless Network of the Universität Regensburg! In less than 30 minutes you will be able to use the Wi-Fi at Universität Regensburg (UR). All you have to do is go through the four steps below. The only thing you need to use the Wi-Fi is a valid CC account with a valid password. windows 1. Connect to basic.uni-regensburg.de Start your computer while you are somewhere on campus. Now you should be able to see several networks. Connect to basic.uni-regensburg.de (Img.1). 2. Open the browser and register You should be automatically redirected to the registration page. (Img. 2: http://register.uni-regensburg.de).?Choose "Neuanmeldung (new registration)" and fill in the forms. It takes about 20-30 minutes for the registration to be valid. 3. Change the Configuration of your Wi-Fi for the UR Stay connected to basic.uni-regensburg.de. Deactivate any additional software tools that configure your Wi-Fi and let the native Windows handle the Wi-Fi.?You can find an easy-to-use programme that configures your Wi-Fi for you at http://www-pc.uni-regensburg.de. The name of the programme is wlanconfig.exe, and the direct link is: http://www-pc.uni-regensburg.de/wlanconfig.exe (Img. 3). 4. Connect to secure.uni-regensburg.de Connect to secure.uni-regensburg.de or secure.hs-regensburg.de respectively, if you study at the Regensburg University of Applied Sciences (Img. 4). First enter your user name and password (Img. 5). Once this authentication is successful you have a secure, encrypted access to our network. ??(Image 5: Enter user name (e.g. vip12345) and password under Windows Vista and Windows 7. You will be asked to choose the profile of the connection on connecting for the first time: Choose ?Public Network.?) Problems connecting? Contact support@rz.uni-regensburg.de or visit the helpdesk. Apple/mac 1. Connect to basic.uni-regensburg.de If you are at the campus of the university, you should be able to receive a list of networks you can connect to. Choose basic.uni-regensburg.de. 2. Open the browser and register Open your browser. It will automatically navigate to our registration website. If you are not automatically proceeded to the site, type in the following URL manually: http://register.uni-regensburg.de Now you have to enter the data necessary for your registration. The registration is valid after 15-30 minutes. Configuration Older Versions Mac OS X Leopard (10.5.x) With Leopard as an operating system, things are a little more complicated, but still manageable if you make the necessary changes in your network menu. (Apple à Properties à Network à Airport) These changes have to be made while you are in reach of secure.uni-regensburg.de! Choose ?Airport? from the connections. If there is no such network it has to be created via the +-icon. Choose secure.uni-regensburg.de from the box of names available for network, then press ?further options?. In these further options you have to do as follows: Choose ?802.1X? Create a new use profile and call it ?Uni Regensburg? Enter your CC account (vip12345) as user name. Do not enter any password here! New Wireless Network: Enter secure.uni-regensburg.de. Choose TTLS encryption and click ?configure?, then choose PAP. Create a new network, call it secure.uni-regensburg.de, choose WPA2 as encryption method and choose ?Uni Regensburg? as a profile. Click ?Add? to finish the process. Mac OS X Panther and Tiger (10.3.9 and 10.4.11) If you are currently using one of the older versions of OS X you can use the wifi 15-30 minutes after your registration. Use the ?airport? symbol to connect to secure.uni-regensburg.de (see below). PLEASE NOTE: You have to change the encryption to TTLS-PAP. Problems connecting? Contact support@rz.uni-regensburg.de or visit the helpdesk. Support for Teaching The computer centre supports teaching by providing different platforms and services including: The G.R.I.P.S E-Learning platform RKS - Regensburg Course Server (Course Administration and registration) E-examinations CIP pool reservation for teaching purposes Student IT Training Student IT Training is offered for all students by Universität Regensburg, in co-operation with the computer centre where participants will gain the necessary skills to professionally handle and design IT and media. My Computers - Universität Regensburg My Computers - Universität Regensburg UR Home Home Computer Centre Your CC Account Change Password Account Balance My Computers Webmail Your Storage Support Software Hardware Teaching and Learning IT Services My Computers Using computers in the data networks of the university (WLAN and LAN) All users at the university with a valid CC account can register their computers, laptops and notebooks so they have access to the university?s data network. Users can register via their personal status page after clicking on the URL http://register.uni-regensburg.de. For registration, the following data need to be filled in: the computer?s location (building and room number) if applicable: use of a special network (administration network, library network etc.) CC account of the person registering the computer CC account of the person for whom the computer is registered eDirectory container of the institute, chair or institution, in the rooms of which the computer is mainly used You will find a list of all the computers, laptops and notebooks used by you on the registration page as well: http://register.uni-regensburg.de. Directions ? How to Get to Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg

Directions ? How to Get to Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg Directions ? How to Get to Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg UR Home Contact Directions Parking Maps Directions ? How to Get to Universität Regensburg By Train Both fast and regional train stop at Regensburg Main Station. It is a station on the railway lines Amsterdam-Vienna and Paris-Prague. Within Germany, train services operate from Berlin/Dresden, Hamburg/Hannover, Dortmund/Cologne, Frankfurt/Stuttgart and Munich to Regensburg. For more information please visit Deutsche Bahn. Once you have arrived at Regensburg Main Station, you can either reach Universität Regensburg by a 20-30 minute walk, by taking a taxi or a bus (Lines 2b, 6 and 11). To find out about bus schedules, please visit the website of the Regensburger Verkehrsverbund. Taking the Bus to Universität Regensburg The buses with the numbers 2b, 4, 6 and 11 des Regensburger Verkehrsverbund will take you to Universität Regensburg. Please get off at the bus stop ?Universität". Those buses (with the exception of the bus with the numbers 4) depart from ?Bustreff Albertstraße? next to the main station. If you own a BahnCard and have bought a long-distance train ticket, you can use all buses of Regensburger Verkehrsverbund free of charge (= City-Ticket). By Car The motorways A3 and A 93 will take you to Regensburg. A 3: Frankfurt ? Nuremberg ? Regensburg ? Passau ? Vienna Exit: ?Universität / Klinikum?; then follow the signposts (?Universität?). International guests using the freeway (in the direction of Passau), please note: The exit ramp to "Universität / Klinikum" is expected to be closed between 17 March until the end of September 2014. For details please see map with directions to Universität Regensburg (pdf). You will get to the university?s underground car park via Albertus-Magnus-Straße that runs underneath the campus. A 93: Munich ? Regensburg ? Hof ? Dresden Exist 43: "Regensburg - Kumpfmühl". After you have passed the traffic light just drive straight on for 2.6 km (via Ludwig-Thoma-Straße). At the second traffic light turn right into ?Universitätsstraße?. At the next crossing turn left into Albertus-Magnus-Straße that runs underneath the campus. This street will also lead you to the university?s underground car park. From German Airports From Munich Airport There is a regular bus service ? number 635 of Münchner Verkehrsbetriebe ? from Terminal 2 to Freising Station. A direct train service from Freising takes to you Regensburg within 60 or 90 minutes. You might also want to use the Airportliner that offers airport transfer from Munich Airport to Regensburg. Please note that this service needs to be booked in advance. From Nuremberg Airport A city bus or the subway will bring you to Nuremberg Main Station. A direct train service (approximately every hour) operates between Nuremberg and Regensburg. The train ride will take between 60 to 90 minutes, depending on the type of train. Referat Kommunikation - 14.03.2014 14:22 Homepage UR Directions

Car parks and underground car parks at Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg

Car parks and underground car parks at Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg Car parks and underground car parks at Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg UR Home Contact Directions Parking Maps Car parks and underground car parks at Universität Regensburg Parking at Universität Regensburg Car parking is provided on campus for the use of staff, students and visitors. There are no parking fees. You may only park on reserved parking bays if you have a special permit. Never park on the forum (the paved area between the main buildings), on grass verges or any areas that are not designated for parking. If you need to drive on the forum, you must apply for a special permit. University Parking Regulations (in German) (PDF/29 KB) Underground car parks - opening times The underground car parks are normally open at the following opening hours: Monday - Friday, 6.30 a.m. ? 0.30 a.m. Saturday, 6.30 a.m. ? 5 p.m. Towed vehicles Never park in areas set aside for special users or in disabled parking bays without a special parking permit. If you do, you may be towed away. Towed vehicles will be taken to the alternative car park opposite the Waste Disposal Centre. It can be reached through Josef-Engert-Straße. To reclaim your towed vehicle, please telephone the towing service on 0172 8128601. You will be provided with a lock code so you can retrieve your car. How to find the car park for towed vehicles (PDF/1 MB) Margit Adler - 18.10.2013 13:06 Homepage UR Parking

Das Corporate Design der Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg

Das Corporate Design der Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg Das Corporate Design der Universität Regensburg - Universität Regensburg Startseite UR Startseite Verwaltung Abteilungen & Referate Ausschreibungen Corporate Design Büromaterial Info-Bildschirme Tutorials Vorlagen Web-Auftritt Formulare & Dokumente Fundbüro / Pforte Materialausgabe und Warenannahme Technische Zentrale Vermietung Webportale und Statistiken Das Corporate Design der Universität Regensburg Das Corporate Design der Universität Regensburg dient dazu, allen Einrichtungen auf unserem Camups ein einheitliches, professionelles und wiedererkennbares Erscheinungsbild zu geben, das gleichzeitig Platz für individuelle Elemente bietet. Das Corporate Design definiert die grafische Gestaltung von Plakaten, Briefpapier, Broschüren und Präsentationen aber auch von Beschilderungen oder Webauftritten. Gestaltungsrichtlinien Das Gestaltungshandbuch der Universität Regensburg informiert Sie über die Richtlinien im Umgang mit dem Logo, der Hausschrift und den Hausfarben der Universität Regensburg. Es erläutert die Funktionsweisen der Vorlagen für den Print- und EDV-Bereich und regelt die Gestaltungsvorgaben für Webseiten. Das Handbuch ist im Dezember 2011 in der zweiten Auflage erschienen. Die gedruckte Version können Sie über das Referat II/2 beziehen. ? Gestaltungshandbuch (PDF/6 MB) Logo und Siegel Das UR-Logo wurde 2005 von Josef Mittlmeier entwickelt und greift als wesentliches gestalterisches Element die "Kugel" am Forum der Universität auf. Das Logo wird grundsätzlich in der Farbe Reingrau verwendet. ? UR-Logo in unterschiedlichen Formaten (Zip-Datei) Das Siegel dient als Emblem und Hoheitszeichen der Universität und wird deshalb ausschließlich für Publikationen der Universitätsleitung, für Zeugnisse und Urkunden verwendet. Ausnähmefälle müssen vom Kanzler der Universität genehmigt werden. Hausschrift Frutiger Next LT W1G Die Hausschrift Frutiger Next LT W1G wird im Printbereich eingesetzt, beispielsweise auf Briefbögen, Aktenvermerken, Broschüren, Plakaten oder Visitenkarten. Bitte beachten Sie: Beim Versand von E-Mail oder bei Powerpoint-Präsentationen verwenden Sie bitte die Systemschriftart Verdana. ? Installation von Frutiger für Windows-Rechner ? Frutiger im Type1-Format Farben Jeder Fakultät oder Einrichtung der Universität Regensburg ist eine eigene Farbe mit hohem Wiedererkennungswert zugeordnet. Diese Farbwelt ergänzt das Reingrau des Universitätslogos zu einem differenzierten Gestaltungsrahmen mit hohem Wiedererkennungswert. ? Farbzuordnung - RGB und CMYK-Werte ? Farbzuordnung - Webfarben Image-Fotografie Das Referat II/2 ? Kommunikation stellt Angehörigen der Universität auf Anfrage kostenfreies Bildmaterial für die Illustration von Faltblättern, Plakaten, Webseiten etc. zur Verfügung. Eine Auswahl unserer Image-Bilder finden Sie in unserem Bildkatalog. Bitte beachten Sie, dass aus rechtlichen Gründen (Urheberrecht, Persönlichkeitsrecht) vor der Herausgabe der Original-Bilddateien die Unterzeichnung einer Nutzungsvereinbarung durch den Leiter oder Leiterin Ihres Instituts / Ihrer Einrichtung / Ihres Referats etc. erforderlich ist. Diese Nutzungsvereinbarung wird Ihnen nach Rücksprache durch das Referat Kommunikation ausgestellt. Um einen reibungslosen Ablauf gewährleisten zu können, beantragen Sie das Bildmaterial bitte mindestens zehn Arbeitstage vor geplanter Fertigstellung Ihres Projekts im Referat II/2-Kommunikation (Mi-Fr. E-Mail: martina.stelzl@ur.de). Bildkatalog (PDF/3 MB) Bei Fragen oder Anmerkungen zum Corporate Design wenden Sie sich bitte an: Universität Regensburg Verwaltung Referat II/2 ? Kommunikation Telefon 0941 943-2304 E-Mail kontakt@ur.de Referat II/2 - 02.10.2013 10:43 Corporate Design Kontakt Referat Kommunikation Telefon 0941 943-2304 kontakt@ur.de

Bitte beachten Sie: Beim Versand von E-Mail oder bei Powerpoint-Präsentationen verwenden Sie bitte die Systemschriftart Verdana. ? Installation von Frutiger für Windows-Rechner ? Frutiger im Type1-Format Farben Jeder Fakultät oder Einrichtung der Universität Regensburg ist eine eigene Farbe mit hohem Wiedererkennungswert zugeordnet. Diese Farbwelt ergänzt das Reingrau des Universitätslogos zu einem differenzierten Gestaltungsrahmen mit hohem Wiedererkennungswert. ? Farbzuordnung - RGB und CMYK-Werte ? Farbzuordnung - Webfarben Image-Fotografie Das Referat II/2 ? Kommunikation stellt Angehörigen der Universität auf Anfrage kostenfreies Bildmaterial für die Illustration von Faltblättern, Plakaten, Webseiten etc. zur Verfügung. Eine Auswahl unserer Image-Bilder finden Sie in unserem Bildkatalog. Bitte beachten Sie, dass aus rechtlichen Gründen (Urheberrecht, Persönlichkeitsrecht) vor der Herausgabe der Original-Bilddateien die Unterzeichnung einer Nutzungsvereinbarung durch den Leiter oder Leiterin Ihres Instituts / Ihrer Einrichtung / Ihres Referats etc. erforderlich ist. Diese Nutzungsvereinbarung wird Ihnen nach Rücksprache durch das Referat Kommunikation ausgestellt. Um einen reibungslosen Ablauf gewährleisten zu können, beantragen Sie das Bildmaterial bitte mindestens zehn Arbeitstage vor geplanter Fertigstellung Ihres Projekts im Referat II/2-Kommunikation (Mi-Fr. E-Mail: martina.stelzl@ur.de). Bildkatalog (PDF/3 MB) Bei Fragen oder Anmerkungen zum Corporate Design wenden Sie sich bitte an: Universität Regensburg Verwaltung Referat II/2 ? Kommunikation Telefon 0941 943-2304 E-Mail kontakt@ur.de Referat II/2 - 02.10.2013 10:43 Corporate Design Kontakt Referat Kommunikation Telefon 0941 943-2304 kontakt@ur.de
Büromaterial im Corporate Design - Universität Regensburg

Büromaterial im Corporate Design - Universität Regensburg Büromaterial im Corporate Design - Universität Regensburg Startseite UR Startseite Verwaltung Abteilungen & Referate Ausschreibungen Corporate Design Büromaterial Info-Bildschirme Tutorials Vorlagen Web-Auftritt Formulare & Dokumente Fundbüro / Pforte Materialausgabe und Warenannahme Technische Zentrale Vermietung Webportale und Statistiken Büromaterial im Corporate Design Briefpapier, Schreibblöcke, Umlauf- und Urkundenmappen sowie Visitenkarten im Corporate Design sind über die Büromaterialausgabe unserer Uni zu bestellen. Preise und Bestellnummern entnehmen Sie bitte dem Lagerkatalog für Büromaterial (PDF/166 KB, nur im Uninetz verfügbar, Suchbegriffe "Briefbogen", "Briefblock, Universität", "Umlaufmappen" und "Repräsentationsmappe"). Für die Bestellung nutzen Sie bitte den Beschaffungsantrag des Referats Einkauf. Visitenkarten Für Visitenkarten steht zum leichteren Bestellvorgang ein PDF-Formular zur Verfügung, mit dessen Hilfe Visitenkarten direkt mit den eigenen Daten ?beschriftet? werden können. Anschließend geht das Formular an die Büromaterialausgabe und von dort weiter an die Druckerei. Ein Päckchen Visitenkarten umfasst 100 Stück, die Kosten betragen ? 41,60 (Stand Wintersemester 2012/13). Bestellformular für Visitenkarten (PDF/133 KB) Bitte beachten Sie: Sollte das Bestellformular ohne ausfüllbare Formulardaten angezeigt werden, öffnet ihr Browser das PDF vermutlich direkt und nicht mithilfe eines Adobe-Plugins. Bitte speichern Sie in diesem Fall das PDF auf Ihrem Desktop ab und öffnen Sie es manuell mit dem Adobe-Reader. Professioneller Vierfarbdruck Das Referat IV/2 (Büromaterialausgabe) ist außerdem Ihr Ansprechpartner, wenn Sie Ihre Broschüren, Flyer, Plakate etc. in einer professionellen Druckerei in Auftrag geben möchten. Für diesen Fall füllen Sie bitte einen Beschaffungsantrag aus und beauftragen das Referat IV/2 mit der Einholung von Vergleichsangeboten und der Auftragsvergabe. Büromaterialausgabe (Referat IV/2) Josef Guggenberger Mensagebäude, Zi. Tutorials für den Umgang mit CD-Vorlagen - Universität Regensburg

Tutorials für den Umgang mit CD-Vorlagen - Universität Regensburg Tutorials für den Umgang mit CD-Vorlagen - Universität Regensburg Startseite UR Startseite Verwaltung Abteilungen & Referate Ausschreibungen Corporate Design Büromaterial Info-Bildschirme Tutorials Vorlagen Web-Auftritt Formulare & Dokumente Fundbüro / Pforte Materialausgabe und Warenannahme Technische Zentrale Vermietung Webportale und Statistiken Tutorials für den Umgang mit CD-Vorlagen Die korrekte Anwendung der CD-Elemente ist im Handbuch beschrieben, das im Dezember 2011 in der zweiten Auflage erschienen ist (CD-Handbuch "Gestaltungsrichtlinien", PDF/6 MB). Um Ihnen die Arbeit mit den Vorlagen für Flyer, Plakate, Briefbögen etc. im Corporate Design zu erleichtern, haben wir Schulungsvideos für Sie vorbereitet. Dort erklären wir Ihnen die wichtigsten Funktionen in den Programmen Adobe InDesign, Adobe Photoshop und MS Word: Wie konvertiert man Bilder in ein für den Druck optimales Bildformat? So arbeiten Sie mit dem Programm Adobe InDesign So können Sie Flyervorlagen bearbeiten Vorbereitung von Flyern für den Druck Anpassung des Briefkopfs im Programm MS Word Wie konvertiert man Bilder in ein für den Druck optimales Bildformat? Das eingebundene Video konnte nicht geladen werden. Klicken Sie hier um das Video in der Mediathek zu öffnen. Dieses Tutorial erklärt, wie Sie Bilddateien mit Hilfe des Programms Photoshop zur Verwendung in Plakaten etc. vorbereiten. Um ein optimales Druckergebnis zu erzielen, müssen Bilddateien im CMYK-Modus abgespeichert werden. So arbeiten Sie mit dem Programm Adobe InDesign Das eingebundene Video konnte nicht geladen werden. Klicken Sie hier um das Video in der Mediathek zu öffnen. Dieses Tutorial zeigt Ihnen, wie Sie im Programm Adobe InDesign ein neues Dokument anlegen und einrichten, wie Sie mit Hilfslinien arbeiten, wie Sie Text eingeben und formatieren, wie Sie Bilder einbinden und erklärt weitere, grundlegende Funktionen. So können Sie Flyervorlagen bearbeiten Das eingebundene Video konnte nicht geladen werden. Klicken Sie hier um das Video in der Mediathek zu öffnen. Hier zeigen wir Ihnen, wie Sie mit der Flyer-Vorlage aus dem Gestalterpaket arbeiten. Unter anderem wird gezeigt, wie man mit CMYK-Farbwerten umgeht, wie man Bilder in den Flyer einfügt und die Textfelder bearbeitet. Vorbereitung von Flyern für den Druck Das eingebundene Video konnte nicht geladen werden. Klicken Sie hier um das Video in der Mediathek zu öffnen. In diesem Schulungsvideo sehen Sie, welche Einstellungen Sie in Ihrem Flyer vornehmen müssen, um die Datei für die Weitergabe an eine Druckerei vorzubereiten. Anpassung des Briefkopfs im Programm MS Word Das eingebundene Video konnte nicht geladen werden. Klicken Sie hier um das Video in der Mediathek zu öffnen. Hier zeigen wir Ihnen, wie Sie im Programm MS Word Änderungen in den Vorlagen für vorgedrucktes Briefpapier vornehmen können. Referat II/2 - 02.10.2013 10:45 Corporate Design Kontakt Referat Kommunikation Telefon 0941 943-2304 kontakt@ur.de

12-seitig; Broschüre A5 mit Umschlag und Innenseiten; Einladungskarten DIN lang 2- und 4-seitig; Antwortkarten DIN lang). Bitte beachten Sie: Nicht alle dieser Vorlagen eignen sich zum Druck auf einem Tischdrucker. MS Word-Vorlagen (Broschüre A5 Innenseiten, Einladungskarte DIN lang, Einladungskarte Actus academicus A5, Antwortkarte DIN lang). Alle Vorlagen bieten wir als komprimierte Zip-Datei zum Download an. Diese Dateien können Sie z.B. mit dem vom Rechenzentrum kostenfrei zur Verfügung gestellten Programm "7-Zip" entpacken. Briefpapier mit vorgedrucktem Logo und entsprechendem farbigen Balken, Schreibblöcke, Umlauf- und Urkundenmappen sowie Visitenkarten im Corporate Design können Sie über die Büromaterialausgabe bestellen. Referat II/2 - 02.10.2013 10:46 Corporate Design Kontakt Referat Kommunikation Telefon 0941 943-2304 kontakt@ur.de

Ihr Web-Auftritt im Corporate Design - Universität Regensburg Ihr Web-Auftritt im Corporate Design - Universität Regensburg Startseite UR Startseite Verwaltung Abteilungen & Referate Ausschreibungen Corporate Design Büromaterial Info-Bildschirme Tutorials Vorlagen Web-Auftritt Formulare & Dokumente Fundbüro / Pforte Materialausgabe und Warenannahme Technische Zentrale Vermietung Webportale und Statistiken Ihr Web-Auftritt im Corporate Design Alle Einrichtungen und Institutionen der Universität Regensburg können ihren Web-Auftritt im Content-Management-System (CMS) der Universität anlegen. Dieses System steht allen Organisationseinheiten kostenfrei zur Verfügung. Um mit dem System arbeiten zu können, melden Sie sich bitte zu einem der CMS-Einführungskurse an, die das Rechenzentrum in Kooperation mit dem Referat für Kommunikation anbietet. Nach der Anmeldung über die E-Learning-Plattform erhalten Sie einen Zugang zu unserem Testsystem; im vierstündigen Blockkurs erklären wir Ihnen die Funktionsweise des CMS und begleiten Sie bei der Erstellung erster Webseiten.
